evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in hist_t3_prefinal.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters based on the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal report.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as detailed in hist_t3_prefinal.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal inspection data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection context.

slot_statements.availability: The mechanical/control failure in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal is present and can be observed or measured.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal is resistant to known defeaters or counterarguments.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features expected for this type of failure in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline t3 prefinal records.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and inconsistencies within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline t3 prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline t3 prefinal data.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: Statements from crew members are accurate and truthful
No other unreported communication occurred that could negate the breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew members during the event
If the crew had explicitly communicated and coordinated to prevent the incident

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly indicates a communication and coordination breakdown among the crew during the pushback, as the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver did not communicate concerns when the aircraft passed the TRP (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions without questioning (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit communication transcripts or recordings; reliance on post-event statements

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal is present and can be observed or measured.

defeaters: Evidence showing mechanical or control system malfunction or failure during the event
Measurements or observations indicating mechanical/control failure
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure was present or observed; all history items describe human actions and situational awareness without mention of mechanical/control failure.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed a marking or environmental deficiency present and observable during the inspection.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or observability of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline t3 prefinal records.

defeaters: If the historical timeline records did not include the procedural deviation or were not accessible in the specified records.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical timeline records (H1-H13) document the pushback event, including the procedural deviation where the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier, confirming the deviation is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline t3 prefinal records.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; the evidence directly documents the procedural deviation in the specified records.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as detailed in hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: The described interactions represent the main communication and coordination among crew during the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors
If the incident was caused by external factors unrelated to crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes communication and coordination failures among the crew, including lack of warnings and assumptions made by crew members (H8, H10, H12), aligning with key features of communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited detail on exact communication protocols and whether all standard procedures were followed

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection context.

assumptions: The TRP described in H7 corresponds to the key features and criteria relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA
Statements about the marking size and signaling methods reflect deficiencies relevant to the environmental or marking deficiency
defeaters: Direct evidence showing the environmental or marking deficiency explicitly matches or mismatches the defined key features and criteria for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection context
Additional documentation or standards defining the key features and criteria for the TRP markings

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 describes the TRP location and clearance relevant to the B737-800, indicating key features for marking. H8 and H13 provide context on the adequacy and perception of the marking and signals, suggesting partial alignment but also deficiencies in marking clarity and signaling effectiveness.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters based on the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal report.

defeaters: Additional evidence showing effective communication or warnings that were ignored
Contradictory testimony indicating clear communication was present

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) directly shows that communication and coordination among the crew were limited and that visual signals were insufficient, with crew members assuming others knew what they were doing and not challenging actions, supporting the claim that the explanation of communication breakdown is resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in crew perceptions and unrecorded verbal communications

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features expected for this type of failure in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction or failure in the tug or aircraft during pushback.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items indicates any mechanical or control failure; all evidence describes human actions and situational details without reference to mechanical or control system faults.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline t3 prefinal data.

defeaters: If additional evidence showed the deviation was due to external factors unrelated to procedural features, or if the TRP markings or procedures were different than described.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes the pushback procedure and deviation from expected stopping at the TRP, with the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast barrier (H4, H7). The tug instructor's method and lack of effective communication or warning signals (H8) and the headset operator's observations (H12) align with the key features of the procedural deviation in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA historical timeline.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether all procedural steps were followed correctly and the subjective interpretation of signals and communication effectiveness.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and inconsistencies within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline t3 prefinal context.

assumptions: The statements from involved personnel are accurate and complete
No additional procedural rules or communications exist outside the provided evidence that would contradict the deviation's acceptance
defeaters: If evidence showed that the headset operator or wingman explicitly warned or objected to the deviation
If there were documented procedural rules strictly prohibiting the actions taken that were enforced or recognized by the crew
If the instructor or other personnel acknowledged the deviation as an error during the event

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows that the procedural deviation was not challenged or contradicted by involved personnel, who assumed the instructor's actions were correct despite the pushback continuing past the TRP and resulting in collision, indicating the deviation withstands counterarguments within the historical context.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication and lack of explicit warnings or objections during the event

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal is resistant to known defeaters or counterarguments.

assumptions: Resistance to defeaters implies robustness against known counterarguments or interventions
The absence of warnings or interventions implies some susceptibility to defeaters
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or intervention by other crew members preventing the failure
If there was a clear mechanical fault that could not be overridden by human action

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that known visual signals to stop the tug were considered insufficient and that the headset operator and wingman did not intervene or warn the instructor, suggesting some vulnerability to defeaters (H8, H10, H12). There is no direct evidence that the mechanical/control failure was resistant to counterarguments.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct evidence on resistance to defeaters; ambiguity about whether human factors or mechanical failure dominated

children_spec.test_procedure: Perform visual and functional inspections to detect any obstructions or blockages in the mechanical control system

children_spec.statement: The procedural deviation is not corrected or mitigated by the flight crew during pushback

children_spec.statement: Ground personnel do not detect or intervene to correct the procedural deviation during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine ground crew reports and surveillance footage to verify if any intervention occurred

children_spec.statement: The aircraft systems do not provide alerts or warnings that prevent the procedural deviation during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze aircraft system logs and alert records to check for absence of warnings related to the deviation

defeaters: If there were documented procedures or technologies ensuring clear, unambiguous communication and marking visibility that were followed, this would increase robustness.
If evidence showed that all personnel consistently recognized and acted on the TRP markings without ambiguity or missed signals.
